posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's like how everyone prefers Luigi to Mario out of contrarianism. Blood is worse than Doom and Quake but liking Blood gives you some gamer street cred so people pretend its the best.
It never ceases to amaze me the mental gymnastics bloodfags go through to justify their shitty game.
The level designs are shit and cultists lazer you without second thought, to play like a pro you don't master the mechanics and encounters, you just quicksave the levels as often times cultists will appear out of nowhere or be in unpredictable places that even the most dynamite happy player would never check.
A fair game allows you a chance to mess up or to beat a scenario on your first going. A good player could beat all of DOOM on ultra violence if they were good enough because the game never throws an unfair or unexpected challenge at you unlike Blood.
Blood has a weak selection on weapons, ultimately this is due to the weak enemy roster and level design. DOOM's chaingun is a good sniper and a decent area clearer, best for big waves or far enemies. The Shotgun is your main gun for normal scenarios. The rocket launcher is great for bulky enemies and the best for huge waves. The Plasma gun is your strongest weapon and is a good all arounder but also scarce. The BFG is your reward for a secret or hard challenge and is the defacto trump gun. Each enemy and level is designed around these inherent weakness and strengths, its why pistol starting is fun. Blood doesn't have this design and most weapons are decent all arounders, the enemies and levels aren't designed around this either. There are few enemies that require you to utilize specific quirks of weapons like the afterburn and most will go down to anything. The levels give you every type of weapon without much thought, like a playground of stuff to mess around with which maybe is fun for a bit but is a weaker experience to DOOM's and Quake's design where the player is not given all the tools at once and needs to be crafty.

Tekken in the arcades was much cheaper than its competition. The first game was basically a PS1 advertisement before the console itself even came out due to running on the same hardware, and it was like a tenth of the price of a Virtua Fighter 2 cabinet.
This meant a lot more installs for those cabinets, especially outside of dedicated arcade halls.
As for the home ports the PS1 was just insanely popular and Tekken, especially 2 and 3, were some of the better 3D fighting games for it.
KI Gold was one of the more expensive home console games sold at the time at 80 bucks, Tekken games were closer to 50 and dipped all the way to 20 with Greatest Hits releases.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9566798
N64 games having high prices didn't necessarily translate to high profit
KI Gold was published by Nintendo so it's hard to say how much Rare ended up making per cart.
However for third parties would end up paying like 20 bucks per cart for even small ROMs, and KI Gold was one of the bigger early N64 games so it's probably closer to half that price being simply manufacturing costs.
Compare this to PS1 where a single disc would cost a couple bucks including royalties to Sony complete in shrinkwrap. So despite being half to a quarter of the retail price the per unit profit of Tekken was significantly higher.

>>9555159
It's possible to force your switch to use the 1.0.0 version of Atari 50 that has Warbirds still in it. The issue is, you need to do a factory reset on your switch. As long as you've let a physical game update, you can't run that game ever in the future without having at least that update. There's some sort of data that remains after you delete data that tells the switch you NEED to update before you can play. Factory reset is the only way to clear that data. Factory reset your switch, then take it offline and put the cartridge in and install the game and disable auto-updates for that game, then your switch should have Atari 50 with Warbirds and can be safely taken back online.
I know your anger, I felt it the day I brought home a PS2 and MGS3 Substance and was all excited to play Metal Gear Online, only to find out they shut the servers down a few months prior.

>This could effect all games on all consoles btw. What's to stop them from sending updates like this to all other collections or standalones? The future looks grim.

It's actually much worse than that. When it becomes sufficiently practical, and eventually it will, mainstream single-player games will not only be online-only but streaming-only. The general public will embrace the convenience of paying a subscription to access all the games in a provider's library, without having to worry about disk space, let alone shelf space. This all-you-can-play model will take the edge off how they don't actually *own* anything in that library, whose contents are subject to change without notice.

There will be nothing for us to back up, unpatch, crack, pirate, or preserve, because all the code and assets will be out of reach on some corporate cloud server. You will have no recourse when they change a game, retire it, or revoke your access for whatever reason.

No matter how digitally locked down they are, movies, music, and ebooks can at least be recorded through the analog hole (i.e. filming the screen), but games will be at the absolute mercy of rightsholders.

t. Cassandra

>>9560002
The Lynx has a custom 16 bit 16Mhz CMOS handling the sprites and rendering the graphics, and a 4Mhz 65C02 (clocked faster than the SNES CPU) handling the general game logic. It also has a dedicated math ASIC that could transform the sprites quickly or something like that. Not even the SNES or Genesis could match the Lynx's performance, let alone the 7800. It's a low res amiga on steroids.

I dunno why people call it the videogames crash of 1983-1985 or 1984. Consoles and arcades were in a decline starting in 1980. Computer gaming was on the rise during the same period. All thanks to the new cheap micro-computers like the Apple II, Atari ST, C64, etc. Computer gaming hit a slump in 1985 until 1988-89 when VGA started getting widespread and not just cutting edge. Consoles hit a slump themselves in 1993 and didn't recover until 1996, and arcades were going down in profits during the same time. Never hear anyone talk about the computer videogames crash of 1985-1988 or the videogames crash of 1993-1996.
The only difference is there was a major recession in the early 1980's. So somehow the recession-related cutback on customer spending is a major videogames crash event, but all the other times the industry has seen their market get cut in half is business as normal. And Nintendo is somehow the savior of videogames for launching the NES at the start of an economic boom period. Never hear anyone say Sid Meier, Jordan Mechner, or Al Lowe saved computer gaming for the growth in PC gaming in 1989.

>mainstream single-player games will not only be online-only but streaming-only.
Google attempted EXACTLY this and it fucking died. Running games from centralized machines and streaming them as footage which the player interacts with remotely is a pipedream bordering on a perpetual motion machine. As harsh as gaming can be in the 2020s, we're actually evading that fate.

People said the same thing about music over 20 years ago during Napster's heyday (though moreso during Limewire's heyday when mainstream music piracy was at its peak), and what ended up happening instead was largely the opposite: vinyl and cassettes making a major comeback. Same with movies; physical libraries were expected to die after Blu-ray got curbstomped by streaming services, and yet we're still getting new movies released on both Blu-ray as well as DVD, the format that Blu-ray was supposed to kill. As of the current gen of vidya, people are still demanding physical releases even from indies, which is how services like Limited Run became a thing (with all of their flaws). Maybe the mainstream will be fugged as you say, but physical will still remain an option as the past two decades have proven against all odds.

>"Buy the Playstation 8, it's not an unresponsive hunk of shit because you aren't on average over 25 miles away from the machine you're actually interacting with, and it doesn't rack up massive bills from constantly streaming live high quality video!"
That one move alone would let Sony (or anyone else) pull out the fucking rug from underneath any competitor trying to do Stadia 2: Electric Jiggaboo, and all the cost and effort required by them would be to do what has always worked very well for them in the past.

This isn't like some DRM scheme or other bullshit where you can kinda hide it away or get people to not think about it too much because it isn't actually fucking enough with their experience at all times, or shitty potentiometer sticks which only last through about a year of use. The bandwidth costs and extreme latency the overwhelming majority of customers would regularly experience trying to use the product are WAY too tangible.
Thus, as a console maker, you have two options:
>A: Do a normal console like usual, and then smugly gloat in all your marketing about how your console is objectively and provably superior, do as well as you always have and watch as the idiots lose all their investments
>B: Set out on the quest to build the massive global infrastructure required to even barely support your competing Suckotron 5000, only to get sidelined by the other parties who weren't retarded enough to do this

It can only ever be dead in the water because you're leaving yourself open to any competitor to trivially have a massive and tangible edge against you which you can never overcome, option A is too profitable to not be your choice. The only way videogames would ever come the point of not having any other option would be if there was some sort of international Video-Hitler enforcing a Stadia cartel at gunpoint.

In the most basic terms, you use scouts to look into what the opponent is doing and you build a counter unit to that. If the game doesn't end in the first 20 minutes, then the strongest economy will win, which means you have to control the map to get more resources. You also need to SPEND said resources (e.g. don't have 8000 wood at the end of the game).

>>9568513
>But analog triggers are a good thing in my POV. They are discrete shoulder buttons that act just like that until the aspirant player try a racing game and learns their magical thing spontaneously
Depends on the triggers. The GC triggers have an enormous amount of travel and relatively high resistance so they work poorly as digital triggers. The Wii Classic Controller and PS2 shoulder buttons are analog but the triggers are very shallow so it's hard to be precise with analog inputs.
I think the Xbox controllers and the DS4 ultimately struck the best balance. And what the Dualsense is doing with adaptive resistance is very interesting too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9570624

> weapons

I didn't express myself clearly. The ammo in SS2 and weapons in SS2 are pretty bog-standard. Pistol, Shotgun, Assault Rifle, Grenade Launcher. The only interesting weapons are the deathbeam thing which is completely useless compared to a Grenade Launcher and the stasis field generator, which is just a glorified massive stun gun that SS1 has immediately in the game.

SS1 has cooler weapon concepts that ramp up much more. You start off with the dart gun that has both tranq and dart ammo, pistols, the flechette with fucking hornet and splinter ammo which is cool, the magnum with hollow point and teflon rounds which is awesome, and at the end you get rail guns and rocket launchers, skorpion machine guns and whatnot.

The plot in SS1 is Hal9000. AI goes insane and tries to kill humanity. It's well written, all bourgeoning empire of steel careening into the sky and all that, but it's pretty simple all through the game. You foil all her individual plans to fuck up earth. Good stuff.

SS2 is philosophical debate between individualism, collectivism and the machine. You are the individual. The Many are collectivism and swarm intelligence, a bit like the Borg in Star Trek. You fuck up collectivism with the help of the Machine, but then it tries to take over again and you, the human individual have to foil the machine to retain humanity. Also it's a debate between organic life and artificial life, and you as an augmented guy are the mixture of both. There's more going on here for SS2 than SS1 imo.

>>9570947
What's mechanically better about it? All the ammo types are still variations of armor piercing and anti-personnel just with different names. The cyber hardware is cool but I mostly just use the jumpjets, shield, and skates and SS2 makes up for those with psionics, speed hypos, and armors. I like SS1 because it's pretty much a sci-fi dungeon crawl but SS2 has the benefits of the Dark engine with great AI, stim and response so you can think outside the box and do things like set yourself on fire with internalized pyrokinesis to avoid protocol droid damage, bash metal pipes to bait shotgun hybrids around corners and ambush them, Eric Brosius' fantastic sound design, and enemies that don't get stuck on corners because of 1994 pathfinding. The only things I can think of that SS1 put more effort into compared to 2 are the minigames which I don't particularly care about, and cyberspace, which I find to be a burden compared to SS2's hacking mechanics, especially when playing on the higher difficulties and you have to do the cyberspace segments in the span of 40 seconds or it resets and you take damage.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Atari were always most comfortable in the arcade style and could never really adjust when games started to get deeper.

An element of that is the fact that they never seemed to understand how integral decent music and sound are to the home gaming experience so they always treated it as an afterthought. The 7800 used the same sound chip as the 2600. The Lynx was touted as having a 32-bit sound processor, but in practice seemed like only a minor sonic upgrade from the 2600/7800. Even on the Jag, stuff like the soundtrack in Tempest 2000 was the exception. Many Jag games didn't even bother with music at all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561389
>The Lynx was touted as having a 32-bit sound processor, but in practice seemed like only a minor sonic upgrade from the 2600/7800
It had an 8 bit 4-channel DAC which could be switched into PSG mode. It could sound nearly as nice as the SNES sound chip provided you gave it good samples. Most Lynx games use the PSG sound mode, perhaps to save some ROM. But in DAC mode, it sounds great.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2NJOJ9roJ9E
>Many Jag games didn't even bother with music at all.
Most Jag games were distributed in 2MB carts. Most developers were too lazy or too poor to hire good musicians to compose great sounding sampled music for them. Tempest 2000 was an exception.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
9561415
Yah Klax has great sound on the Lynx. So that would be an exception too.

Every platform at the time had limits but made due. My point was that Atari just never seemed to think audio was that important to begin with. Otherwise they would have made some different choices. In hindsight it's something that definitely hurt them, even though it's not usually mentioned as such.

Its got tons of games, so let me recommend you the games the NES couldn't possibly replicate instead. There's not even a NES equivalent for Star Raiders, atari's 1979 killer app on an 8 bit cart. The sequel looks even more impressive. There's star luster for the NES, but it looks horrible and plays worse. LucasArts 3D fractal games are also excellent, the NES couldn't run any of them. The Seven Cities of Gold is a huge open world action RPG slash strategy game, NES didn't have enough RAM for that kind of thing. posts.name: Anonymous

>>9566841
>atari 8-bit is atari's 8-bit line of home computers
It was built for gaming. It had sprite system, projectile system, 4 channel sound chip, cart slot, and some BASIC clone that sucked because Atari cheaped out on that.
>it was the only powerful 8-bit home computer until commodore 64 came along. both C64 (commodore 64) and atari 8-bit is the only powerful 8-bit computers of the 80s
Now that's stupid. Yes the Atari 8-bit and C64 had a powerful sprite system, but others had their own strengths. The BBC Micro was a 6502 computer clocked at a whopping 2MHz, Elite ran smooth as a butter on it. ZX Spectrum could update its screen faster than any bitmap graphic home computer of its days. The CPC was, I think, the only 8 bit computer with no colour attribute limitations, and it was pretty fast too considering what it was. The PC-88 had a really high screen resolution.
But yes, for gaming purposes, nothing beat the Atari 8-bit and C64.
>if you mean atari st's processing speed then yes, it is far powerful than amiga
Of course, blast processing beats the 'migger.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9571552
Especially when the leading creatives behind Doom were either already of the opinion that fans should tinker with the game, or would be convinced that it was a great idea all along after seeing what people were doing with it.

Carmack and Romero had seen what people did when tinkering and fucking around with Wolfenstein 3D, and they loved it because as kids they would tinker and fuck around with games themselves. They concluded though that it was kind of lame that you essentially had to convert your game files to run fan made content, so if you wanted to undo it or try another one, you had to uninstall the game and install it again, and this was something they wanted to do better for Doom, which would be one of the main reasons for the .wad file format.

Now, Doom modding wasn't actually that flexible out of the gate, but you could in fact load a custom made .wad which had new levels, music, and textures, and you didn't need to fuck with doom.wad, the .exe would load it on top. This still left sprites, the engine would refuse to load just a partial set of sprites from your other .wad, it had to replace no sprites or all of them, but the community pretty quickly devised a utility which would let you patch the contents of a custom .wad onto doom.wad, but then also revert it back to its original state.
With the patching utility, and also figuring out how to hack the .exe to change a lot of things which a level editor or .wad editing program couldn't, people got really creative, leading to all kinds of ambitious projects, such as Aliens TC and multiple Star Wars mods, efforts which really blew the guys at iD away, things which would gradually win over even the skeptics at the office as people just kept making cool shit like that.

Around 1997, Carmack gets convinced to release the source code for Doom, and he tells people to go nuts, try adding stuff like free mouselook, jumping or sloping floors, even go for broke and get the game running in OpenGL.

posts.com:
>>9569198
It does use 8x16 sprite mode, I don't know a single Konami game which doesn't (perhaps early ones?), and that is precisely why it flickers more.

Imagine that other sprites are on the same X axis as the first 8x8 pixels of the sprite. In 8x8 sprite mode, only that 8x8 sprite will ficker, but in 8x16 mode, the entire 8x16 sprite will flicker, thus effectively flickering an area twice as big for the same situation.
8x16 mode has other pros, but its con is that it leads to flickering bigger sprites.

What was your first experience playing Doom?
>late 1994 sunday afternoon
>7yr old me, obsessed with Mortal Kombat 2
>don't read gaming magazines, out of the loop about PC games in general
>dad brings home a big box with cool artwork and floppies inside
>"drop your nintendo, anon, I've got something here"
>"nooo dad, not your simulators again"
>(I actually loved playing F117 with him but all I wanted to play at the moment was Mortal Kombat 2)
>"It's a shooter game like contra but it's in first person like you are watching the action with your own eyes, anon"
>"yeah dad, like in your simulators. This is a really stupid idea"
>dad switches on the PC. I don't like it much because "Super Nintendo has cooler games" and I'm always afraid to break it somehow. I am not allowed to switch it on and use it on my own
>Windows 3.1 starts but dad shuts it down to "free the memory"
>starts a blue-windowed shell instead
>I am looking at the game box while the game installs. It says Doom II
>some of my classmates were joking about Doom when the lights went flickering in the class. Never seen the game myself and never knew that there are two of them
>after the setup process the game is launched, first level starts, I see pic related
>"huh, these stairs look cool"
>dad moves around, shoots
>"definitely cool"
>I ask to try myself and for the rest of the session it's just me playing and dad watching me play and giving advice
>we finish the game a couple of weeks later. Keyboard only, frequently getting scared and lost in the levels, save scumming
>It's the best gaming experience in my life, thanks dad.

>>9560493
For $5000 you could get a brand new Pentium computer around 1993 and have about half left over (people didn't do this at the time). Doom only needed a 486 to run well, which hovered at around $1000 at the time, and would keep dropping. By the time Doom 2 was in stores, a 486 computer with a mouse and the memory to use it together with the game would be WELL under the $1000 mark. Not to talk about the older and much cheaper 386 machines which would run the game well enough in low detail mode and the screen size cut down a step or two, with the original game's first episode being widely available dirt cheap, or even for free. Most people probably experienced it this way, many using the 386 or even 486 at their school, university, or workplace.
That's in addition to said PC, even on the lower end, being capable of playing MANY other good games, as well as all kinds of office, work, and utility software.

To conclude, your dad should have pulled out, because clearly he couldn't afford to raise you if the prospect of playing Doom was prohibitively expensive. You must have grown up somewhere incredibly poor and undeveloped.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9561281
>For $5000 you could get a brand new Pentium computer around 1993
You'll need that if you want full and consistent framerate.
>Doom only needed a 486 to run well
With basic ass 486DX-33, you needed to set the quality to minimum and reduce the window size by 25% or less to get a comfortable framerate.
>which hovered at around $1000 at the time
More like $2000 for the basic ass 486DX-33. Even a shitty 386DX would be well over $1000. A bare minimum spec PC with 486DX2 66MHz, the minimum CPU for running Doom comfortably, would run you up for almost $2500. 486SX was choppy as hell and with 486DX you needed to scale down the screen size by something like 25% and set the quality down to minimum, but it will still get choppy when the game throws more enemies at you. Not sure if using more RAM than the minimum spec of 4MB will help the game run better, I suppose it does at higher quality and resolution.
>Not to talk about the older and much cheaper 386 machines which would run the game well enough in low detail mode and the screen size cut down a step or two
More like in half or less.
>That's in addition to said PC, even on the lower end, being capable of playing MANY other good games, as well as all kinds of office, work, and utility software.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561337
>You'll need that if you want full and consistent framerate.
If you wanted the full 35fps at all times, sure, but the vast majority of people hadn't ever experienced that with a game of that graphical fidelity (compare to Ultima Underworld). The game being able to stay consistently above 20fps was already incredibly fluid for most people at the time. Compare.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=foHUXGzHOx0

Never mind that you definitely did not have to spend up to $2500. You didn't have to buy a complete pre-built, you could build your own, even reuse components from an older computer (such as the screen, keyboard, mouse, speakers), depending on what you start out with, you could even replace the 386 on the motherboard with a 486, and a weaker 486SX can be replaced with a better 486DX, the previous one can be sold off to cover expenses. You can also save a lot by skipping a CD-ROM drive, which would start at like $200 alone by 1994, Doom was available on floppies.

If you had already invested in a 386 prior, you didn't need to spend a fortune on getting decent performance with Doom, nor did you if you had a lower end 486. Some computers with 486s could also be upgraded to Pentium, which could become relevant for later games.

posts.com:
>>9570581
I think it boils down to: newer technology ≠ better look, and more realistic lighting ≠ better lighting.
Old games had very limited lighting, thus everything appeared perfectly lit. All the bright colors were intact and you had naturally sharp picture with contrast. So games often looked more "picturesque" if it makes sense.
As things moved towards global lighting and closer to photorealism / ray tracing, it came at the expense of color, sharpness and contrast. Every era introduced its own slew of shit meme tech of the time (see: X360's bloom and plastic look).
With ray tracing, everything looks like a photo—but a shitty photo you took with your phone in midday sunlight. That's why movies need artificial lighting, they will look like shit otherwise. Ray tracing puts a cross on sharpness, you will always have overly soft dim image with washed out colors.

Its too bad, the devs definitely seemed passionate and had some good ideas that just were not fleshed out. The stage mash ups were neat. I actually thought the combat could get more intense then smash, like yea its dumb you need a combo gauge to ko, but when both people have one and you are both trying to get in close and land that one hit, it was kinda like a better sudden death match in smash.

I think the biggest issue it had, is ultimately the curse of most video game crossovers that is not Smash, outside of Nintendo, most fan demographics are not "hardcore", by which i mean, a Nintendie will probably recognize 85% of a roster in Smash, but the same amount of Playstation cultists that would recognize a roster of PS characters is a much smaller demographic. Like it sounds like the devs wanted more characters a hardcore gamer would have recognized associated with playstation systems, but most people buying those consoles, were never doing so for Sony ips. So them you are trying to sell this crossover celebration to a audience who only buys your systems for call of duty or madden, then getting upset you aren't reaching those sales, while at the same time not giving the money or support to the devs to make something that will atleast please hardcore gamer nerd/Sony heads. So it was kinda fucked from the start which is a shame. Being surface level clone of smash didn't help either.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9570887
The final PPU revision they did was Rev G, introduced in 1989 and which allowed you to read from the PPU registers and OAM table, while they were write-only on previous revisions. Famicoms with the hockey stick logo have this chipset, but for NESes there was no obvious visual cue. However, the introduction of the Rev G chipset coincided with Nintendo introducing fireproofed ABS plastic shells which turn yellow, while older units do not yellow. If you have a yellowed NES it likely has the Rev G chipset but running Micro Machines is the only way to confirm it as the title screen will glitch on older hardware revisions.

Some later games such as Kick Master and possibly Wario's Woods may in fact read from the PPU registers and do not work on units made before 1989. This shouldn't have passed Q/C checks but Nintendo usually weren't that good. Typically the playtester would just stick it in whatever console he had on hand, and if the game ran, then it passed. I heard of one game (was it from Software Creations? I don't remember) that did this and failed Q/C because they tested it on an older Rev E NES so they had to go back and redo everything.

Before I knew how programming worked (and I figured it out quickly, learned BASIC and then C++ by the fourth grade), I thought games were just constructed entirely by hand by the way the circuit boards were laid out. RIP Caveman Games. I don't think you were a very good game, but you never worked again after that.

It really is amazing just how much value you can get out of the PS1, even though the console is no longer $20 on average.
>loose PS1 current price = $35
>composite cable and power cable = $15 for the pair
>PS1 controllers = $12 each
>PS1 memory cards = $11 each
>PS1 modchip = $3 if you shop around
For $76 you can be playing the entire library if you know how to solder, $88 will let you bring a friend, and $99 will let him have his own memory card for his Diablo character. Another $16 gets you a Gameshark and the ability to fuck around with games and do stuff like skip the license tests in Gran Turismo. The only other retro home console that comes close in terms of value is the Sega Genesis with the $42 flash cart.

Alright OP I changed my mind, if you are truly a zoomer here's what I recommend.
- Pick up SEGA Genesis Classics on platform of choice
- For more Genesis, check out the Genesis Mini 1 or 2 which include a few more games
- For Dreamcast stuff, check out Dreamcast Collection on Xbox 360 or Steam (the latter includes more games like JSR and NiGHTS for some reason)
- For more SEGA games, try out Sonic's Ultimate Genesis Collection on 360/PS3, SEGA Classics on PS2, or any other SEGA compilations like 3D Classics on 3DS
This will give you a quick look at SEGA's history on whatever modern platform you're playing on. Some games like Monster World IV also have full blown modern remakes.

I think it's a very cool console that was not used to its potential. Like the Sega CD, it was held back by the era of FMV and prerendered rail shooters (not my favorite personally). Many of its games came from PC or were later ported to it/other consoles, but it does have a handful of exclusives or superior versions of games.

Favorite games I have played:
Alone in the Dark
Crash 'N Burn
Gex
Lucienne's Quest
Road Rash
Need for Speed

I don't know that there's really enough interesting titles to merit buying one to the average retro gamer, but I think fans of the bridge between the 4th/5th gen can appreciate some of its titles. If you're buying a US console get the original, the iconic Panasonic FZ-1.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9570616
Let's get the obvious part out of the way now.
Infamously, the 3DO was handled worse than the Sega Saturn because they royally priced themselves out of the consumer market. On average it would retail for like $700 at the time, which was fucking ludicrous, for that money you could go and grab both a SNES and Genesis (derided as babies toys in 3DO marketing material) with a bunch of great games and a pair of controllers each.

Now, to the 3DO's games. Quarantine was nice, a bit tedious, but the soundtrack appealed to me a lot. Even if the port of Doom was botched, Wolfenstein 3D was great, and Killing Time was quite decent. The port of Super Streetfighter 2 Turbo was great.
I only played them on PC, but Myst and Syndicate were available on 3DO, and I imagine they'd be just as good.
Another I didn't play, but heard of over the years, was a game called Immercenary, the title alone standing out, apparently it's pretty good if you're willing to give it a chance.

Well, there's 5 distinct time periods on Earth, 6 other planets in the Solar System, and all of them have unique dungeons with 10 floors of hand-crafted layouts, and a unique castle, town, and village. So the point stands - no other RPG of that time was as ambitious.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9567254
there's no real "first one" because there's no arbitrary limit that makes something a bullet hell or not. Stuff like DDP is considered by everybody to be a bullet hell, stuff like Tiger Heli definitely isn't, but Batsugun and Garegga are in a weird in-between, with some emphasis on micro-dodging from time to time, but with a fairly big hitbox, low bullet count and density, which makes them feel like prototypes for bullet hell.
Batsugun isn't even too different from V-V when it comes to bullets, and that came out a few months before, so that would make V-V the first one.

>>9567840
Tiger-Heli has more bullet curtains than most classic shmups to be honest, but I guess you are talking about patterns from a single enemy.

I think the main defining factor is small hitbox, which is intrinsic to all the gameplay and design surrounding it. To me, danmaku's signature style is a tiny little hitbox, slow bullets with tiny hitboxes, dull and static backgrounds, a shot covering a large portion of the screen (at least 50%), uninspired art and sound, and constant hordes of enemies littered without intent or care that just form a long flowing chain.

I would say Batusugun Original is only like 40% danmaku, and Batsugun Special is maybe 60%

2 and 3 don't have this problem, because they are mechanically solid under the surface, the added difficulty on top of the bonuses only serves to complement the game's combat.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9570690
The problem with using anything but the original stick for N64 games is that certain things get broken due to the fact that no other analog stick works the same way. The gates around the stick that give you certain angles physically lock off the maximum range of the stick, and other sticks don't. So aiming sucks in any game that needs aiming (also because the N64 stick requires more pressure to move it), and things like smash attacks in smash or the spin attack in OOT/MM are broken with any other stick, Mario's walking, loads of other things too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9570690
I have a retrobit tribute 64 wireless for pc emulation and using on my n64.
I personally don't like it because so much of the n64 for me is how distinct the original controller is.
And even though the gamecube stick fixed virtually everything wrong with the original n64's analogue, it still just feels wrong to use for the authentic n64 experience.
I do realize I'm in the minority on this.

But otherwise, controller is great - buttons feel very similar and that's what counts

>>9571171
I feel like more than this, the thread is built on a false assumption that fighters were the only graphics demo genre. Recall that Sega flexed their shit more on driving games like Virtual Racing and Daytona USA. If anything, VF stuck out to people because it was rendering humans. People don't care about impressive cars so much as they do about impressive people.

Doom and Quake blew minds because it was 3D (or 3D enough) and real-looking on a computer. Then of course it kept going and going with new functionality or visuals (HL2 showing off havok physics for example) before what others pointed out (and which I still think is a peak given how graphics no longer pay to push that hard) the release of Crysis just blew everybody away. But needless to say, those genres where you can see a body or a person are more appealing for graphics whoring than vehicles, because people are so much harder to do. To their credit, graphics now for rendering people are pretty incredible, even if I personally am not as impressed by just outright scanning a face as I am by modeling them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9560878
Here in Sweden (and apparently the rest of Scandinavia), Nintendo was the big thing and Sega was much rarer. They got around, I've seen clearance bins with old Mega Drive sports game once or twice, so people were buying them, but I personally saw only one Mega Drive console ever as a kid, otherwise it was NES, SNES, Game Boy, N64, and then of course PC and PSX.

I was actually kind of bummed about that, because I did occasionally hear about Sega games from kids at school and that they were different in a cool way, and I had seen the Sonic cartoons on TV, but the games were just not anywhere and I never got to try them. At the time, this felt like this mythical counterpart which had simply eluded me, and I wondered about it sometimes.
Until the very late 90s and early 2000s that is, when emulation really began taking off, not only did I now have free access to the fabled SNES which I had only ever gotten to try out a few times, but now the Mega Drive actually was within my grasp. The first game I tried was Shining Force, and I was SO hooked, I would play nothing but that game for a month.

Emulation got pretty popular around my circles, because it was endless free games, people would check out the consoles they never had when they were younger, or titles they missed for the ones they did have. It also worked as Early Access, I got to play Pokémon before it launched here, and then Gen 2 before it even left Japan (with a shitty and half done fan translation, of course).
